Causal Estimands

We consider a setting in which nn subjects, labelled i=1,...,ni = 1, ..., n, enter a study at baseline (time t=0t=0) and are subjected to treatment A0,iA_{0, i}. In a clinical trial, the value of A0,iA_{0, i} is determined by the study protocol, usually at random. In an observational study, A0,iA_{0, i} is observed and recorded. A collection of covariates, C0,iC_{0, i}, are also measured at baseline. At the subsequent follow-up visits, the time-varying confounders, Lt,iL_{t, i} and treatment At,iA_{t, i} are recorded, t=1,...,Tt = 1, ..., T. An outcome YiY_i is observed for each subject, measured at the final visit TT, YiY_i can be continuous or binary.

Along with the YiY_i for each subject, for each possible realization of the treatment history aâ€¾âˆˆğ’œâ€¾\bar{a} \in \bar{\mathcal{A}}; we also define Yiaâ€¾Y_i^{\bar{a}}, the that would have been observed had the subject, possibly contrary to fact, received treatment history aâ€¾\bar{a}.

In a simple setting with 3 visits, assume the following DAG. Under the static, fixed treatment regimes, the overall causal effect of the exposures changing form the 25th25^{th} percentile to the 75th75^{th} percentile can be defined as:

ACE=E[YA0=a0*,A1=a1*,A2=a2*]âˆ’E[YA0=a0,A1=a1,A2=a2]ACE = E[Y^{A_0 = a_0^*, A_1 = a_1^*, A_2 = a_2^*}] - E[Y^{A_0 = a_0, A_1 = a_1, A_2 = a_2}] where a0,a1,a2a_0, a_1, a_2 are the 25th25^{th} percentile of the exposures, a0*,a1*,a2*a_0^*, a_1^*, a_2^* are the 75th75^{th} percentile of the exposures.

g-formula

The basic idea of g-formula is standardization, a common approach to estimating the expected value of Yaâ€¾Y^{\bar{a}} in the population. (Naimai, Ashley I., et al., 2017) It can be illustrated in a simple time-fixed confounding example where there are only baseline confounders C0C_0 where the sum is over all possible values c0c_0 of C0C_0. E(Yaâ€¾)=âˆ‘C0E(Yâˆ£Aâ€¾=aâ€¾,C0=c0)P(C0=c0)E\left(Y^{\bar{a}}\right)=\sum_{C_{0} } E\left(Y \mid \bar{A}=\bar{a}, C_{0}=c_{0}\right) P\left(C_{0}=c_{0}\right) where the sum is over all possible values c0c_0 of C0C_0.\

Using the above DAG, we now define 3 identifying assumptions:\

  1. Consistency: E[Y|A0=a0,A1=a1,A2=a2]=E[Ya0,a1,a2|A0=a0,A1=a1,A2=a2]E[Y | A_0 = a_0, A_1 = a_1, A_2 = a_2] = E[Y^{a_0, a_1, a_2}| A_0 = a_0, A_1 = a_1, A_2 = a_2]

  2. Exchangeability:

  3. Positivity: Pr(at|atâˆ’1,lt,c0)>0for all values oflwithPr(L=l)â‰ 0Pr(a_t|a_{t-1}, l_t, c_0) > 0 \ \text{for all values of} \ l \ \text{with} \ Pr(L = l) \ne 0

The general expression of the g-formula for a static fixed intervention is: E[Yaâ€¾]=âˆ‘lâ€¾E[Yâˆ£Aâ€¾=aâ€¾,Lâ€¾=lâ€¾,C0=c0]âˆt=0Tf(ltâˆ£aâ€¾tâˆ’1,lâ€¾tâˆ’1)f(c0)]\begin{equation} E[Y^{\bar{a}}]= \sum_{\bar{l}} \mathrm{E}[Y \mid \bar{A}=\bar{a}, \bar{L}=\bar{l}, C_0 = c_0] \prod_{t=0}^{T} f\left(l_{t} \mid \bar{a}_{t-1}, \bar{l}_{t-1} \right)f(c_0) \end{equation}]

Bayesian kernel machine regression

We first review Kernel Machine Regression (KMR) as a framework for estimating the effect of a complex mixture when only a single time point of exposure is measured. For each subject i=1,...,ni = 1, ..., n, we assume

Yi=h(ğši)+ğœiTğ›ƒ+Ïµi\begin{equation} Y_{i}=h\left(\mathbf{a}_{i}\right)+\mathbf{c}_{i}^{\mathrm{T}} \boldsymbol{\beta}+\epsilon_{i} \end{equation} where ğši=(ai1,â€¦,aiM)T\mathbf{a}_{i}=\left(a_{i 1}, \ldots, a_{i M}\right)^{\mathrm{T}} is a vector of MM exposure variables.

It can be shown that the above model can be expressed as the mixed model yiâˆ¼N(hi+ğœiTğ›ƒ,Ïƒ2)y_{i} \sim N\left(h_{i}+\mathbf{c}_{i}^{T} \boldsymbol{\beta}, \sigma^{2}\right)

ğ¡â‰¡(h1,â€¦,hn)Tâˆ¼N(ğŸ,Ï„ğŠ)\begin{equation} \mathbf{h} \equiv\left(h_{1}, \ldots, h_{n}\right)^{\mathrm{T}} \sim N(\mathbf{0}, \tau \mathbf{K}) \end{equation}

where ğŠ\mathbf{K} is the kernel matrix, has (i,j)âˆ’(i, j)-element K(ğši,ğšj)K(\mathbf{a}_{i}, \mathbf{a}_{j})

There are different choices of the kernel. We focus on the Gaussian kernel, which flexibly captures a wide range of underlying functional forms for h(â‹…)h(\cdot), although the methods are applicable to a broad choice of kernels. We assume cor(hi,hj)=exp{âˆ’(1/Ï)âˆ‘m=1M(aimâˆ’ajm)2}\operatorname{cor}\left(h_{i}, h_{j}\right)=\exp \left\{-(1 / \rho) \sum_{m=1}^{M}\left(a_{i m}-a_{j m}\right)^{2}\right\} where Ï\rho is a tuning parameter that regulates the smoothness of the dose-response function. This assumption implies that two subjects with similar exposures will have more similar risks (aia_i to aja_j, and hih_i will be close to hjh_j ).

Bobb et al (2015) presented the Bayesian Kernel Machine Regression (BKMR) as a framework to estimate the effect of a complex mixture on a health outcome.

To fit (2), we assume a at prior on the coefficients for the confounding variables, Î²âˆ¼1\beta \sim 1, and
Ïƒâˆ’2âˆ¼Gamma(aÏƒ,bÏƒ)\sigma^{-2} \sim \operatorname{Gamma}\left(a_{\sigma}, b_{\sigma}\right), where we set aÏƒ=bÏƒ=0.001a_{\sigma} = b_{\sigma} = 0.001.

We can parameterize BKMR by Î»=Ï„Ïƒâˆ’2\lambda=\tau \sigma^{-2}, and we assume a Gamma prior distribution for the variance component of Î»\lambda. For the smoothness parameter Ï\rho, we assume Ïâˆ¼Unif(a,b)\rho \sim \operatorname{Unif}(a, b) with a=0a=0 and b=100b=100. For additional details regarding BKMR and prior specifications, see Bobb et al.Â (Bobb et al., 2015, 2018)
